headline: CNN Live Event/Special
subHeadline: Now: Biden Enters House Chamber For State Of The Union Address; Education Secretary Miguel Cardona Is The Designated Survivor; Momentarily: Biden Speech To Joint Session Of Congress. Aired 9-10p ET

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF JAKE TAPPER, CNN ANCHOR AND CHIEF WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: And not just IVF, but also contraception, right? And that's a big -- major issue, the Democrats are starting to talk about, how Republicans will be coming for contraception after this.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF HUNT
utterances.sentences: Right. And that was -- that was a warning in the Dobbs decision, right, from the dissenters, from the liberal justices. They said, look, this is a slippery slope.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Republicans dispute this, of course, we should note. But there are--

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF HUNT
utterances.sentences: They do.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --legislators, here and there, who have that--

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF HUNT
utterances.sentences: I mean, when you believe that fertilization that -- that life begins at conception, there are some consequences there. And when you start to talk about the technologies, I mean, it's entirely, we're seeing unintended consequence.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF ABBY PHILLIP, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Just--

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF HUNT
utterances.sentences: Let's just put it that way.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Just to note, I mean, how important this issue is. Dozens of Democrats have brought guests, related to IVF, and--(CROSSTALK) VOICE OF HUNT: Including the first lady.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Including the first lady. So, that's another way that they show their priorities for this address. That's, from what we've gathered from the President's excerpts of his speech, it's going to be a big part of his remarks.It's also the most, I mean, maybe second to democracy, if you're talking about base Democratic voters, probably the most important issue for them is reproductive rights, in this election. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Not as surprising, by the way, that none of the -- none of the Democrats, as far as I know, brought anyone related to -- there's the first lady and President Biden. They have made it to the Capitol.Let's listen in.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. President, how are you feeling?

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: Great.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That's the second, how are you feeling, and great, of the evening.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF DAVID CHALIAN, CNN POLITICAL DIRECTOR
utterances.sentences: Well from good to great, right?

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: From good to great. Well, he got reinvigorated--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: --reinvigorated in the car with his grandchildren.But it's kind of surprising that nobody brought a guest, related at all, to the prosecution of Donald Trump. Because you could say -- I would not put it above any politician to bring, say, E. Jean Carroll, or anyone like that. Maybe they are in there. But that's something else that's -- a cloud over all of this is the fact that Donald Trump, who President Biden will be facing in November, has all these legal problems, Kaitlan.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. And as MJ Lee reported earlier, that Joe -- Joe Biden -- President Biden is not expected to say Donald Trump's name. But he won't have to. I mean, it's going to loom over this entire situation. House Republicans know that as well.And that's why, when you talk to the White House, they say the headline from tonight, though he will be talking about those other issues, democracy is going to be the takeaway. And so, when you see the Supreme Court justices, and think about what a big role they are playing, in this election that we are about to see, in when President -- former President Trump is going to potentially face his trial, for his attempts to overturn the election, it's hard to ignore what a presence the Supreme Court is, in this room, and what dynamic and impact they are going to have on this election.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And if you -- if you -- you've seen a couple familiar faces flashed in the last minute. One of them was George Santos.Another one, in between, right there, in between John Roberts, the Chief Justice and Sonia Sotomayor, behind them, that's Justice Kennedy, Anthony Kennedy, who resigned from the Supreme Court. I believe he was replaced by -- was it Brett Kavanaugh, who took his place? And--

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF CHALIAN
utterances.sentences: Correct, yes.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So that -- that is, it's interesting, I suppose.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: As with George Santos, he still enjoys privileges. Not to compare, Justice Kennedy, and Congressman Santos.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF JOHN KING, CNN CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes. And--

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But they are both formers. There we see Lisa Murkowski and Susan Collins, both of whom, in the last couple weeks, endorsed Nikki Haley, talking to Lindsey Graham.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF JAMIE GANGEL, CNN SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, who did not endorse Nikki Haley. He is still with Donald Trump.Just to go back to something that John King was mentioning earlier, about the debate and things that are important. A number of centrist Democratic sources, and frankly, moderate Republican sources, who want Biden to win, over Trump, said to me, this afternoon, he better talk about crime. He better talk about immigration, and the border. They see these, as just along with reproductive rights, a critical message.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF KING
utterances.sentences: And again, this is where you get this debate, among Democrats, because overall, violent crime statistics are down, nationally. They are down. So Democrats bristle. They say no, you're playing into the Fox News argument. No, you're playing into the Republican argument.But in major cities, the Democratic governor of New York just mobilized the National Guard, to deal with subway crime, in New York City. And so, this is again, a debate in the party, about do you -- if you talk about it, are you playing their game? But you're absolutely right. If you talk to Democratic pollsters, and the people who run the numbers, amongst swing voters, suburban voters, the people, who decide close presidential elections, they are very disappointed, in the President's performance, on crime and immigration.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And if -- and if you talk to Democrats, about the bad polling, for President Biden, the thing they will say is, you can look at polls, all you want, we're looking at elections.And they -- they're talking about the fact that since the Dobbs decision, since Roe v. Wade was overturned, in the special elections, and a referenda, in states, whether red states like Kansas and Ohio and Montana, or the special election, in New York, Democrats have won, and the pro-choice or pro-abortion rights side has won. There's Congressman Matt Gaetz. And they're hopeful that that will help Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF HUNT
utterances.sentences: It will. And can we just talk for a second? We've seen a lot of the Supreme Court justices, who are down on the floor, tonight, and how, what a -- what a unique position they occupy, this time. I mean, yes, they always -- there's always a cadre of them, at these speeches. It has become increasingly political, over the years.I mean, I was sitting in the gallery, when Samuel Alito mouthed at President Obama, that what he was saying, about a Supreme Court decision, about election funding was not true. And that was seen at the time, as something that was very remarkably -- a remarkably political statement, from one of these justices. But they literally sit at the very heart of the election that Joe Biden -- President Biden is up there, tonight, fighting for, in a way that they have not been, certainly since 2000, in Bush versus Gore, and possibly ever, in terms of having to decide whether or not President Biden's opponent is going to be able to be charged in the, you know, for basically sending a mob, to this very building, on January 6th, 2021.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And you know what though (ph)? It's important to point that out. But one thing I will say, about the view, from the Biden campaign, and from the White House, is that they are not looking to these criminal cases, against Trump, to play the role in this election. They do not think that that is going to be what this is going to turn on. And there are a lot of people, out there, talking about how -- it isobviously important for democracy, for the country. But they understand that the prospects of these cases, being concluded before the election, not great. The prospect of them being definitive, and going in any particular way, and moving voters, in any particular way, is too uncertain. What they do know, though, and I think to Jake's earlier point, they're not wrong, when they say that voters have been voting, in a way, that sometimes differs from what they say to pollsters, about how happy or unhappy they are, about Joe Biden, or even the direction of the country. The reason for that is abortion. But the reason for that is also because of choices that they have, at the ballot box.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Let me--

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And when Republicans put up candidates, who are on the far-right, and they don't choose their candidates properly? That has made a huge difference in these races. And they think that's how they see November, at the top of the ticket, as well.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Let me bring in Evan Osnos, right now, who is -- who has been President Biden's biographer, just did an interview with him for The New Yorker magazine.Evan, do you think this is the most important speech, of President Biden's career?

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF EVAN OSNOS, BIDEN BIOGRAPHER, STAFF WRITER, THE NEW YORKER
utterances.sentences: You know, he's had a very long career, Jake, as you know. But I think it is a credible case to make.Look, this is an unusual moment, because it is both the chance for him to try to talk about what he's done. And then, he is also making his biggest pitch, to the largest audience, he's going to have, before November. I was talking to somebody, who is very close to him. And I said, how do you think he handles the pressure of a moment like this? And they said, look, to be honest, he's been dealing with pressure like this, his entire adult life. The weirdest moment for him was when he wasn't under pressure, when he was in that period after his first -- after the Obama presidency.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Evan, let me just interrupt for one second. I'm sorry. I'll come right back to you.But there we see, the second gentleman, Doug Emhoff, the husband of the Vice President, Kamala Harris, who you see there, on stage. Doug Emhoff, who has become one of the administration's leading voices, on the rise of anti-Semitism in the United States. Doug is Jewish. There, he just waved at his wife. And she seems to be smiling at her -- at her goofy husband, in an affectionate way. Evan, back to you.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: There is the first lady of the United States, Dr. Jill Biden, taking her seat, next to the second gentleman, or near the second gentleman, surrounded by what are called Scott Nicks (ph), that is special guests of the President of the United States, there to illustrate various policy points, and ways that what the administration has been doing, has affected them.There's the former House Speaker, Nancy Pelosi. President Biden is running late, we should note. He is in a holding room, right now.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF HUNT
utterances.sentences: Par for the course.(GAVEL BANGS)

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And he is -- there is the Speaker gaveling in the session.Should we listen in? Let's listen in.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Speaker, the President's Cabinet.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The President's Cabinet walking in, right now.Obviously, there is the Secretary of State, Antony Blinken, who has been rather busy, these days, what with all sorts of crises in Ukraine, in the Middle East. Followed by the Secretary of the Treasury, Janet Yellen. (APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Secretary of Defense, Lloyd Austin, whose health issues became something of a problem, for the administration, when he failed to disclose them, even though he had been hospitalized. Thankfully, his health is good.Evan Osnos, it is quite a balancing act, for President Biden, as we -- David Chalian outlined all the things, all the things he needs, to achieve with this speech. You see other members of the President's Cabinet there. The Secretary of Agriculture, Tom Vilsack; the Secretary of Commerce, Gina Raimondo, and on and on. Is it Deb Haaland, who is the designated?

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF COLLINS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: We do not know yet?

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It is--

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: We don't know?

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I just saw a picture of her.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Oh, so it's not her?

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I just saw a picture of Deb Haaland. She just posted a picture with the many members of the Cabinet.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Oh, so it's not her.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The one we don't see is Gina Raimondo. I'm not saying it's her.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: No. We just saw her on the floor.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF CHALIAN
utterances.sentences: That was -- we just saw her there.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: We just saw Gina Raimondo.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF COLLINS
utterances.sentences: So, she's the only one--

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: We are trying -- sorry folks, at home. We are trying to figure out a nerdy D.C. parlor game, which is -- yes, there's the Secretary of the Interior, Deb Haaland. So, not her.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF KING
utterances.sentences: There's Deb Haaland.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Who is the designated survivor kind of a dark thing, a dark tradition in this in this country, about who will maintain the continuity of government, should the worst possible thing, in the history of the known universe happen, to this building that we're looking at right now. There is always somebody, from the Cabinet, who does not attend. There's the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, Alejandro Mayorkas, who was impeached by the House of Representatives, for, in their view, the Republicans in the House, not carrying out his duties at the border. The border, obviously a huge issue.There's Secretary of Transportation, Pete Buttigieg.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well I believe it's the Education Secretary, Miguel Cardona.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Miguel Cardona is the Secretary of Education, we believe, is the designated survivor.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Waiting for--

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: But John King, the issue of the border?You see Alejandro Mayorkas, right there, the Secretary of the Department of Homeland Security, who was impeached, although the Senate is not going to take up that issue, so he will not be removed from office. And even if they were to take it up, the votes would not be there. How much -- like what to say, if you are President Biden, and this is such a huge issue, immigration and the problems at the border? And obviously, Republicans have been talking about the border problems, for quite some time.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And if you're wondering who gets those great seats in the -- by the aisle, so that they can shake hands with, for instance, the United Nations Ambassador, the -- those seats are coveted, quite a bit. People come early.Manu Raju is in Congress, right now. And Manu, like how did Joe Manchin get that sweet spot?

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF MANU RAJU, CNN CHIEF CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: He brought -- he had someone saving it for him, Jake. In fact, a lot of these members, this is -- that's actually kind of unusual. In the past, people had been here for hours and hours and hours, holding the seats. This time, they had people saving them.But I want you to key in on when Joe Biden enters the room, he'll be greeted by some of his fiercest critics, in the House GOP, some Republican hardliners, who are sitting right as he enters. Congresswoman Lauren Boebert, sitting near the entrance, and next to Congressman Matt Gaetz, and there's Congressman Marjorie Taylor Greene also sitting very close to the aisle. Both Boebert and Marjorie Taylor Greene told me, earlier today, that they will not be afraid, to yell back at Joe Biden, if they feel like that, in their view, he is saying something untruthful, or something that they don't like. And Marjorie Taylor Greene, of course, was someone, who said that Joe Biden was a liar, during last year's State of the Union address, something that Speaker Mike Johnson absolutely does not want to see. So, how will they greet the President, when he enters? That's a question. When Jill Biden was just introduced, the first lady, Marjorie Taylor Greene was seated, while the rest of the chamber was have -- giving a standing ovation, Jake.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes, we should point out, just for fairness sake, that, Joe Biden was not lying about what he brought up, when Congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene yelled, liar, he had been saying that there were Republicans proposing sun-setting services, like Medicare and Social Security, and they in fact were.But that was a deft moment, for President Biden, concerns about his acumen, and alacrity, notwithstanding he was able to take that moment, and ad-lib, and say, oh, so members of the Republican Party, you agree with me? Let's listen in for this big, big, big moment for President Biden.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAM MCFARLAND, SERGEANT AT ARMS OF THE UNITED STATES HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES
utterances.sentences: Mr. Speaker, the President of the United States. (CHEERS & APPLAUSE)(NOW: BIDEN ENTERS HOUSE CHAMBER FOR STATE OF THE UNION ADDRESS) (CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE) REP. TIM BURCHETT (R-TN): (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Keep looking this way. Keep looking this way.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Don't let -- don't focus on them (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (inaudible) all right.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. President.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We love you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We'll cover here. Mr. President.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You are making us (ph) happy Joe.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We have been seeing, Mr. President. We have been seeing, Mr. President.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is about you. This is about the changes you're (ph) making.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is about the changes you're (ph) making.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This is about the changes you're (ph) making.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. President, you see Barbara. You see Barbara Lee, right here.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Barbara Lee.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You see Barbara Lee.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. President.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Let me closer to the (inaudible).(LAUGHTER) (CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Mr. President.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. President.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Keep moving.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, keep going. Keep going.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Over here, Mr. President.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Over here, Mr. President.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Over here.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: How are you doing? Today is the 59th anniversary of Bloody Sunday.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I know and (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, good.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: It's today.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Good, good, good.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: How are you, Mr. President?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Here we go.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You got it?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: OK.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, sir.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible) Joe, oh my. You're doing a good job.SEN. JOE MANCHIN (D-WV): (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I'll tell you what (inaudible) come back.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: All right (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. President.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you for everything. You are the best.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We got to get the good stuff over here.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh my god.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It is. It is.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. You're doing great tonight.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Joe, you are the best.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: When you look out and see all this white, you know we're wearing it for you.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh (inaudible). Well.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: How are you doing tonight?(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I'm the last member (ph).

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: OK. You're going to do great.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: They're going to be yelling you out.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: They're going to be yelling (ph) too, so.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I love you. Come on let's take the selfie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Just hold still (ph).(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).(DEMOCRATS CHANTING "FOUR MORE YEARS")

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Chief, how are you?

utterances.speaker: JOHN ROBERTS, CHIEF JUSTICE OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Really good to see you.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: God bless you (ph).McFarland, I'm going this way?

utterances.speaker: MCFARLAND
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir.(DEMOCRATS CHANTING "FOUR MORE YEARS") (CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So, President Biden making his way down the aisle, greeting all sorts of members of Congress. You saw some people, trying to say hi, affectionately. Some people challenging him, for various reasons. He is greetings -- greeting his, the Joint Chiefs of Staff now.This is one of the great moments, in American politics, watching the President, whoever he is, come down and see all the branches of government. You see people in both major political parties. There is a common purpose, no matter what the nastiness that has been said. There is some degree, even during the harsh political times, of fellowship, and camaraderie. Jamie Gangel.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes, no, it's obviously very harsh times. And look, you saw him walk in. And one of the more loud members, of the Republican Party, Marjorie Taylor Greene, Congresswoman from Georgia, put on a MAGA hat.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF HUNT
utterances.sentences: Which is not allowed.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Which is not allowed.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF HUNT
utterances.sentences: I have to say.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: You're not allowed to do that. And I mean, according to the rules of the House and the Senate.

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF HUNT
utterances.sentences: The House.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And she was wearing a pin, referring to Biden's border crisis, quote-unquote, and challenging him to say the name of Laken Riley, the University of Georgia student killed, recently, in a tragic accident, a tragic incident rather, a murder by an undocumented Venezuelan immigrant.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: VOICE OF TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Here he is, presenting copies, of his State of the Union address, to the Vice President and, of course, to the Speaker of the House. Let's listen in.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Good evening.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Where is Jill?(GAVEL BANGS) (CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Good evening.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE) BIDEN: Good evening. If I were smart, I'd go home now. (LAUGHTER) (CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Mr. Speaker, Madam Vice President, Members of Congress, my fellow Americans, in January 1941, Franklin Roosevelt came to this chamber to speak to the nation, and he said, I address you in a moment, unprecedented in the history of the union.Hitler was on the march. War was raging in Europe. President Roosevelt's purpose was to wake up Congress, and alert the American people that this was no ordinary time. Freedom and democracy were under assault in the world. Tonight, I come to the same chamber, to address the nation. Now, it's we who face unprecedented moment in the history of the union. And yes, my purpose tonight is to wake up the Congress, and alert the American people that this is no ordinary moment either. Not since President Lincoln and the Civil War have freedom and democracy been under assault at home as they are today. What makes our moment rare is that freedom and democracy are under attack at both at home and overseas at the very same time. Overseas, Putin of Russia is on the march, invading Ukraine, and sowing chaos throughout Europe and beyond. If anybody in this room thinks Putin will stop at Ukraine, I assure you, he will not. (CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: But Ukraine--(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Ukraine can stop Putin.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Ukraine can stop Putin, if we stand with Ukraine and provide the weapons--(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: --that it needs to defend itself.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: That is all--(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: --that is all Ukraine is asking. They're not asking for American soldiers. In fact, there are no American soldiers at war in Ukraine, and I'm determined to keep it that way.(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: But now, assistance to Ukraine is being blocked by those, who want to walk away from our world leadership. Wasn't long ago when a Republican president, named Ronald Reagan, thundered, "Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall."(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Now--(CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Now, my predecessor, a former Republican president, tells Putin, quote, do whatever the hell you want.(BOOING)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: America is a founding member of NATO, the military alliance of democratic nations, created after World War II, prevent -- to prevent war and keep the peace.And today, we've made NATO stronger than ever. We welcomed Finland to the alliance last year. (CHEERS & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Unemployment at 50-year lows.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: A record 16 million Americans are starting small businesses. And each one is a literal act of hope.  With historic job growth and small-business growth for blacks and Hispanics and Asian-Americans, 800,000 new manufacturing jobs in America, and counting.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Where is it written we can't be the manufacturing capital of the world?We are, and we will. (APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: More people have health insurance today...(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: More people have health insurance today than ever before. The racial wealth gap is as small as it's been in 20 years. Wages keep going up. Inflation keeps coming down. Inflation has dropped from 9 percent to 3 percent, the lowest in the world, and tending lower.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: The landing is and will be soft.And now, instead of importing -- importing foreign products and exporting American jobs, we're exporting American products and creating American jobs... (APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: ... right here in America, where they belong.(APPLAUSE) BIDEN:  And it takes time, but the American people are beginning to feel it. Consumer studies show consumer confidence is soaring. "Buy America" has been the law of the land since the 1930s. Past administrations, including my predecessor, including some Democrats as well in the past, failed to buy American. Not any more. On my watch, federal projects that you fund, like helping build American roads, bridges and highways, will be made with American products and built by American workers... (APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: ... creating good-paying American jobs.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And thanks to our CHIPS and Science Act, the United States is investing more in research and development than ever before. During the pandemic, a shortage of semiconductors, chips, that drove up the price of everything from cell phones to automobiles -- and by the way, we invented those chips right here in America.(APPLAUSE) (UNKNOWN):  We did!

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, instead of having to import them -- instead, private companies are now investing billions of dollars to build new chip factories here in America, creating tens of thousands of jobs...(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: ... many of those jobs paying $100,000 a year and don't require a college degree.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: In fact, my policies have attracted $650 billion in private- sector investment, in clean energy, advanced manufacturing, creating tens of thousands of jobs here in America.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And thanks -- and thanks to our Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, 46,000 new projects have been announced all across your communities.And by the way, I notice some of you who strongly voted against it are there cheering on that money coming in. (APPLAUSE) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I like it.(APPLAUSE) BIDEN:  I'm with you. (APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Folks -- for the folks at Belvidere, I say, instead of your town being left behind, your community is moving forward again because instead of watching auto jobs in the future go overseas, 4,000 union jobs with higher wages are building the future in Belvidere right here in America.(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Here tonight is UAW president Shawn Fain, a great fan and a great labor leader.Sean, where are you? Stand up. (CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And Dawn. And Dawn Simms, a third-generation worker, UAW worker at Belvidere.Shawn, I was proud to be the first president to stand in the picket line. And today, Dawn has a good job in her hometown, providing stability for her family and pride and dignity as well. Showing once again Wall Street didn't build America. They're not bad guys. They didn't build it, though. The middle class built the country and unions built the middle class. (CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I say to the American people, when America gets knocked down, we get back up. We keep going. That's America.(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: That's you, the American people. It's because of you America is coming back. It's because of you our future is brighter. It's because of you that tonight we can proudly say the state of our union is strong and getting stronger.(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE) (CROWD CHANTS "FOUR MORE YEARS)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Tonight -- tonight I want to talk about the future of possibilities that we can build together. A future where the days of trickle-down economics are over. And the wealthy and the biggest corporations no longer get all the tax breaks. And by the way, I understand corporations. I come from a state that has more corporations invested than every one of your states in the United States combined. And I represented it for 36 years.I'm not anti-corporation, but I grew up in a home where trickle-down economics didn't put much on my dad's kitchen table. That's why I determined to turn things around so middle class does well. When they do well, the poor have a way up and the wealthy still do very well. We all do well. And there's more to do to make sure you're feeling the benefits of all we're doing. Americans pay more for prescription drugs than anywhere in the world. It's wrong, and I am ending it. (CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: With a law that I proposed and signed, not one of your Republican buddies voted for it, we finally beat big pharma. Instead of paying $400 a month or thereabouts for insulin with diabetes, it only cost 10 bucks to make, they only get paid $35 a month now and still make healthy profit. (CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And I want -- what to do next? I want to cap the cost of insulin at $35 a month for every American who needs it. Everyone.(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: For years, people have talked about it, but finally we got it done and gave Medicare the power to negotiate lower prices on prescription drugs. Just like the V.A. is able to do for veterans. That's not just saving seniors money, it's saving taxpayers' money. We cut the federal deficit by $160 billion.(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: They're making a lot of money, guys.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And they will still be extremely profitable.It will not only save lives; it will save taxpayers another $200 billion. (CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Starting next year, the same law caps total prescription drug costs for seniors on Medicare at $200 -- $2,000 a year, even for expensive cancer drugs that cost $10,000, $12,000, $15,000.And I want to cap prescription drug costs at $2,000 a year for everyone. (CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Folks, I'm going to get in trouble for saying it, but any of you want to get in Air Force One, we can fly to Toronto, Berlin, Moscow -- I mean -- excuse me -- and -- well, even Moscow, probably.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And bring your prescription with you, and I promise you I will get it for you for 40 percent the cost you're paying now, same company, same drug, same place.Folks, the Affordable Care Act, the old Obamacare, it's still a very big deal. (LAUGHTER) (CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Over 100 million of you can no longer be denied health insurance because of a preexisting condition. Well, my predecessor and many in this chamber want to take those -- that prescription drug away by repealing Affordable Care Act.(BOOING)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to let that happen.(CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: We stopped you 50 times before, and we will stop you again.(CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: In fact, I'm not only protecting it. I'm expanding it.The -- the enacted tax credits of $800 per person per year reduced health care costs for millions of working families. That tax credit expires next year. I want to make that savings permanent. (CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: To state the obvious, women are more than half our population, but research on women's health has always been underfunded.That's why we're launching the first ever White House Initiative on Women's Health Research led by Jill, doing an incredible job as first lady. (CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: We will pass my plan for $12 billion to transform women's health research and benefit millions of lives all across America.I know the cost of housing is so important to you. If inflation keeps coming down, mortgage rates will come down as well, and the Fed acknowledges that. But I'm not waiting. I want to provide an annual tax credit that will give Americans $400 a month for the next two years as mortgage rates come down to put toward their mortgages when they buy their first home or trade up for a little more space. (CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: That's for two years.(CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And my administration is also eliminating title insurance on federally backed mortgages.(CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: When you refinance your home, you can save $1,000 or more as a consequence.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: For millions of renters, we're cracking down on big landlords who use antitrust laws -- using antitrust -- who break antitrust laws by price-fixing and driving up rents.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: We have cut red tape, so builders can get federally financing, which is already helping build a record 1.7 million new housing units nationwide.Now pass... (CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Now pass and build and renovate two million affordable homes and bring those rents down.(CHEERING AND APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And I, like I suspect all of you, want to give a child, every child, a good start by providing access to preschool for 3 and 4 years old.(APPLAUSE) You know,  I think I pointed out last year... (APPLAUSE) I think I pointed out last year that children coming from broken homes, where there's not books, they're not read to, they're not spoken to very often, start school, kingergarten or first grade hearing - having heard a million fewer words spoken. Well, studies show that children who go to preschool are nearly 50% more likely to finish high school, go on to earn a two- and four-year degree no matter what their background is. (CHEERING & APPLAUSE) BIDEN: I met a year and a half ago with the leaders of the business roundtable, they were mad that I -- they were angry. I said, well, they were discussing why I wanted to spend money on education. I pointed out to them as Vice President, I met with over 8 -- I think was 182 those folks don't hold me the exact number and I asked them, what they need most, the CEOs and you've had the same experience of both sides now. They say a better educated workforce, right? So I looked at them, and I say I come from Delaware, DuPont used to be the eighth largest corporation in the world and every new enterprise they bought they educated the workforce to that enterprise, but none of you do that anymore. Why are you angry with me providing you the opportunity for the best educated workforce in the world? They all looked at me and said, I think you're right. I want to expand high quality tutoring and summer learning to see that every child learns to read by third grade. (CHEERING & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I'm also connecting local businesses in high schools so students get hands-on experience and a path to good paying job whether or not they go to college. And I want to make sure the college is more affordable.(CHEERING & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Let's continue increasing the Pell Grants to working in middle- class families and increase record investments. In HBCU, the minority serving institution including Hispanic institution.(CHEERING & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And I was told I couldn't universally just change the way in which you did -- that was student loans. I fixed two student loan programs that already existed to reduce the burden of student debt for nearly four million Americans including nurses, firefighters, and others in public service. Like Keenan Jones, a public educator in Minnesota who's here with us tonight. Keenan, where are you?Keenan, thank you. He's educated hundreds of students so they can go to college. Now, he's able to help after debt forgiveness get his own daughter to college. (CHEERING & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And folks, look, such relief is good for the economy because folks are now able to buy a home, start a business, start a family while we're at it. I want the public-school teachers a raise.(CHEERING & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And by the way, the first couple years, we cut the deficit. Now, let me speak to the question of fundamental fairness for all Americans. I've been delivering real results in fiscally responsible ways. We've already cut the federal deficit. We've already cut the federal deficit over a trillion dollars. I signed the bipartisan deal to cut another $1 trillion in the nextdecade. It's my goal to cut the federal deficit another $3 trillion by making big corporations, the very wealthy, finally beginning to pay their fair share. (CHEERING & APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Look, I'm a capitalist, if you want to make or can make a million or millions of bucks, that's great. Just pay your fair share in taxes.(CHEERING & APPLAUSE)
